docblock.description: Text representation of interface types.

tag.name: var
tag.description: Text representations of interface types.

docblock.description: Get the number of network interfaces (regardless of their current state) present on this system.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The number of network interfaces on the system

docblock.description: Get an array of device MTUs

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of device MTUs

docblock.description: Get an array of the interfaces' physical addresses
docblock.long-description: "The interface's address at the protocol layer immediately `below' the network layer in the protocol stack. For interfaces which do not have such an address (e.g., a serial line), this object should contain an octet string of zero length."

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of device physical addresses

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface admin status (up / down)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the follow SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.7.10128 = INTEGER: up(1) .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.7.10129 = INTEGER: down(2) ...

 [10128] => 1
 [10129] => 2

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface admin states

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface last change times
docblock.long-description:
Value returned is timeticks (one hundreds of a second)

"The value of sysUpTime at the time the interface entered its current operational state. If the current state was entered prior to the last re- initialization of the local network management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Timeticks (or zero) since last change of the interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface in octets
docblock.long-description: "The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of octets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface unicast packets in
docblock.long-description: "The number of subnetwork-unicast packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of unicast packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface non-unicast packets in
docblock.long-description: "The number of non-unicast (i.e., subnetwork- broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of non-unicast packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface inbound discarded packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of discarded inbound packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface inbound error packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface indexes
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.1 = INTEGER: 1 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2 = INTEGER: 2 ...

 [1] => 1
 [2] => 2

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface indexes

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface names

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface names

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface aliases (e.g.
docblock.long-description:
as set by the interface description / port-name parameter)

E.g. the followig SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10128 = STRING: Connection to switch2 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10129 = STRING: Connection to switch3 ...

 [10128] => "Connection to switch2"
 [10129] => "Connection to switch3"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface aliases

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface descriptions
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10128 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/28 .1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10129 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/29 ...

 [10128] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/28"
 [10129] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/29"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface descriptions

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface (operating) speeds
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10128 = Gauge32: 1000000000 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10129 = Gauge32: 100000000 ...

 [10128] => 1000000000
 [10129] => 100000000

NB: operating speed as opposed to maximum speed

WARNING: This is a 32 bit int so it cannot represent 10Gb links. These would show up as:

 [10127] => 4294967295

Instead, use highSpeeds() which will represent the speed as Mbps

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface operating speeds

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface (operating) speeds
docblock.long-description:
From Cisco:

"An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range ofn-500,000' to `n+499,999'. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero."

E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10127 = Gauge32: 10000 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10128 = Gauge32: 1000 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10129 = Gauge32: 100 ...

 [10127] => 10000000000
 [10128] => 1000000000
 [10129] => 100000000

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface operating speeds

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface operating status (up / down)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the follow SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10128 = INTEGER: up(1) .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10129 = INTEGER: down(2) ...

 [10128] => 1
 [10129] => 2

docblock.description: Utility function to gather channel details together in an associative array.
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of support channel types. For example:

Array
(
    ....
    [SIP] => Array
        (
            [name] => SIP
            [index] => 5
            [description] => Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)
            [hasDeviceState] => 1
            [hasProgressIndications] => 1
            [canTransfer] => 1
            [activeCalls] => 0
        )
    ....
)

If you chose to index by SNMP table entries, the above element would be indexed with 5 rather than SIP.

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, the array is indexed using the SNMP table index rather than the unique channel type name

tag.name: return
tag.description: Channel details as an associative array

docblock.description: Utility function to gather together all the details of individual channels into an array.
docblock.long-description:
Essentially, this function calls all chanXXX() functions to return the details for individual channels gathered together. E.g.

Array
(
    ....
    [SIP/foobar-654-00000372] => Array
    (
        [chanName] => SIP/foobar-654-00000372
        [chanLanguage] => en
        [chanType] => SIP
        [chanMusicClass] => (null)
        ...
        [chanVariables] => Array
        (
            [DIALEDPEERNUMBER] => foobar-654
            [SIPCALLID] => 1be189fa6281ffc1108db32935f05016@192.168.7.7:5060
        )
        [chanFlags] => 1020
        [chanTransferCap] => speech
    )
    ....
)

The function returns an array of all channels. Unknown parameters within the channel are set to null.

An empty array is returned if there are no active channels.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Translate parameters when possible

tag.name: param
tag.description: Rather than indexing the outer array with the unique channel name, index with the SNMP table position

tag.name: return
tag.description: All the details of individual channels into an array.

docblock.description: Returns the system services of the device
docblock.long-description:
"A value which indicates the set of services that this entity primarily offers.

The value is a sum. This sum initially takes the value zero, Then, for each layer, L, in the range 1 through 7, that this node performs transactions for, 2 raised to (L - 1) is added to the sum. For example, a node which performs primarily routing functions would have a value of 4 (2^(3-1)). In contrast, a node which is a host offering application services would have a value of 72 (2^(4-1) + 2^(7-1)). Note that in the context of the Internet suite of protocols, values should be calculated accordingly:

layer  functionality
    1  physical (e.g., repeaters)
    2  datalink/subnetwork (e.g., bridges)
    3  internet (e.g., IP gateways)
    4  end-to-end  (e.g., IP hosts)
    7  applications (e.g., mail relays)

For systems including OSI protocols, layers 5 and 6 may also be counted."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The system services of the device

docblock.description: Gets all system values as an associate array
docblock.long-description: The keys of the array are contact, description, location, name, services, uptime

tag.name: return
tag.description: All system values as an associate array

docblock.description: Returns the BGP version
docblock.long-description: "Vector of supported BGP protocol version numbers. Each peer negotiates the version from this vector. Versions are identified via the string of bits contained within this object. The first octet contains bits 0 to 7, the second octet contains bits 8 to 15, and so on, with the most significant bit referring to the lowest bit number in the octet (e.g., the MSB of the first octet refers to bit 0). If a bit, i, is present and set, then the version (i+1) of the BGP is supported."

tag.name: return

docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the ConnectRetry timer. The suggested value for this timer is 120 seconds."

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the Hold Timer established with the peer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the Hold Timer established with the peer. The value of this object is calculated by this BGP speaker by using the smaller of the value in bgpPeerHoldTimeConfigured and the Hold Time received in the OPEN message. This value must be at lease three seconds if it is not zero (0) in which case the Hold Timer has not been established with the peer, or, the value of bgpPeerHoldTimeConfigured is zero (0)."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the Hold Timer established with the peer.

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer established with the peer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer established with the peer. The value of this object is calculated by this BGP speaker such that, when compared with bgpPeerHoldTime, it has the same proportion as what bgpPeerKeepAliveConfigured has when compared with bgpPeerHoldTimeConfigured. If the value of this object is zero (0), it indicates that the KeepAlive timer has not been established with the peer, or, the value of bgpPeerKeepAliveConfigured is zero (0)."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer established with the peer.

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the Hold Time configured for this BGP speaker with this peer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the Hold Time configured for this BGP speaker with this peer. This value is placed in an OPEN message sent to this peer by this BGP speaker, and is compared with the Hold Time field in an OPEN message received from the peer when determining the Hold Time (bgpPeerHoldTime) with the peer. This value must not be less than three seconds if it is not zero (0) in which case the Hold Time is NOT to be established with the peer. The suggested value for this timer is 90 seconds."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the Hold Time configured for this BGP speaker with this peer.

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer configured for this BGP speaker with this peer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer configured for this BGP speaker with this peer. The value of this object will only determine the KEEPALIVE messages' frequency relative to the value specified in bgpPeerHoldTimeConfigured; the actual time interval for the KEEPALIVE messages is indicated by bgpPeerKeepAlive. A reasonable maximum value for this timer would be configured to be one third of that of bgpPeerHoldTimeConfigured. If the value of this object is zero (0), no periodical KEEPALIVE messages are sent to the peer after the BGP connection has been established. The suggested value for this timer is 30 seconds"

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the KeepAlive timer configured for this BGP speaker with this peer.

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the MinASOriginationInterval timer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the MinASOriginationInterval timer. The suggested value for this timer is 15 seconds."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the MinASOriginationInterval timer.

docblock.description: Returns Time interval in seconds for the MinRouteAdvertisementInterval timer.
docblock.long-description: "Time interval in seconds for the MinRouteAdvertisementInterval timer. The suggested value for this timer is 30 seconds"

tag.name: return
tag.description: Time interval in seconds for the MinRouteAdvertisementInterval timer.

docblock.description: Returns Elapsed time in seconds since the last BGP UPDATE message was received from the peer.
docblock.long-description: "Elapsed time in seconds since the last BGP UPDATE message was received from the peer. Each time bgpPeerInUpdates is incremented, the value of this object is set to zero (0)."

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour addresses indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: The (first) network-layer address of the device as reported in the Address TLV of the most recently received CDP message. For example, if the corresponding instance of cacheAddressType had the value 'ip(1)', then this object would be an IPv4-address. If the neighbor device is SNMP-manageable, it is supposed to generate its CDP messages such that this address is one at which it will receive SNMP messages. Use cdpCtAddressTable to extract the remaining addresses from the Address TLV received most recently."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour addresses indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours (by their CDP ID) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours connected port description indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description:
E.g. a sample call may return:

Array
(
    [10101] => GigabitEthernet0/1
    [10102] => FastEthernet0/2
    [10103] => GigabitEthernet1/0/24
    [10105] => GigabitEthernet1/0/2
)

meaning, for example, that our local port with ID 10101 is connected to port GigabitEthernet0/1 on the neighbour connected to that local port. You can discover the neighbour ID via neighbourId().

The Port-ID string as reported in the most recent CDP message. This will typically be the value of the ifName object (e.g., 'Ethernet0'). The zero-length string indicates no Port-ID field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours connected port *description* indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour platforms indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: The Device's Hardware Platform as reported in the most recent CDP message. The zero-length string indicates that no Platform field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour platforms indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: The Device's Functional Capabilities as reported in the most recent CDP message. For latest set of specific values, see the latest version of the CDP specification. The zero-length string indicates no Capabilities field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: see
tag.description: "Cisco Discovery Protocol Specification, 10/19/94."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Query if a given neighbour (by connected port ID) has the given capability
docblock.long-description:
Example:

if( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourHasCapability( $portId, \OSS_SNMP\SNMP\MIBS\Cisco\CDP::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH )
     echo "Host is a switch!!";

tag.name: param
tag.description: The CDP neighbour by connected local port ID

tag.name: param
tag.description: The capability to query for (defined by self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_XXX constants)

tag.name: return
tag.description: True if the neighbour has the given capability

docblock.description: Get an array of individual capabilities of a given neighbour (by connected port ID)
docblock.long-description:
Example:

print_r( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourCapabilities( 10111 ) )

    [0] => 8         // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH
    [1] => 32        // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_IGMP_CAPABLE

print_r( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourCapabilities( 10111, true ) )

    [0] => "Switch"              // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH
    [1] => "IGMP Capable"        // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_IGMP_CAPABLE

tag.name: param
tag.description: The CDP neighbour by connected local port ID

tag.name: param
tag.description: Set to true to return descriptions rather than integers

tag.name: return
tag.description: Individual capabilities of a given neighbour

docblock.description: CDP utility function to get all CDP neighbours and their connected ports.
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of neighbours indexed by the neighbour CDP ID with a lot of details.

For example, here's a sample return for a switch with two neighbours where one neighbour is connected with a LAG / PortChannel and $inverse was set to true.

array(2) {
    ["cr-sw07.example.ie"] => array(1) {
        [0] => array(7) {
            ["localPortId"] => int(10103)
            ["localPortName"] => string(7) "Gi1/0/3"
            ["localPort"] => string(20) "GigabitEthernet1/0/3"
            ["isLAG"] => bool(false)
            ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/24"
            ["remotePortId"] => int(10124)
            ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/24"
        }
    }
    ["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(2) {
        [0] => array(11) {
            ["localPortId"] => int(10111)
            ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11"
                ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11"
            ["isLAG"] => bool(true)
            ["lagPortId"] => int(5048)
            ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
            ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11"
            ["remotePortId"] => int(10111)
            ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11"
            ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048)
            ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
        }
        [1] => array(11) {
            ["localPortId"] => int(10112)
            ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12"
            ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12"
            ["isLAG"] => bool(true)
            ["lagPortId"] => int(5048)
            ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
            ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12"
            ["remotePortId"] => int(10112)
            ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12"
            ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048)
            ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
        }
    }

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, all remoteXXX params will be discovered (only remotePort is returned otherwise)

tag.name: param
tag.description: If using $inverse, pass an array of CDP IDs of neighbours that should not be 'inverse' discovered.

tag.name: return
tag.description: CDP neighbours and their connected ports

docblock.long-description: Array form is same as that returned by neighbours()

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant array of all crawled devices (same as that passed in the @param $devices parameter)

docblock.description: Find the layer 2 topology as an array with no link mentioned more than once.
docblock.long-description:
Huh? This function:

  • takes the result of crawl() (or calls crawl()) to get the CDP topology;
  • foreach device, builds an array of device to device links;
  • SO LONG as that link has already not been accounted for in the other direction.

I.e. if a link is found A -> B, then the same B -> A link will not be included.

The primary differences to the return value of this and crawl() are:

  • links only appear once (unidirectional) rather than twice (bidirectional)

  • the links are indexed by the localPortName rather than an integer index:

    [cr-sw04.degkcp.example.ie] => Array ( [cd-sw02.degkcp.example.ie] => Array ( [GigabitEthernet1/0/3] => Array ( [remotePort] => FastEthernet0/1 [isLAG] => false ........ ) )

All port information is copied over from the supplied / called crawl() array

tag.name: param
tag.description: The result of crawl() (if null, this function performs a crawl())

tag.name: return
tag.description: L2 topology as described above.

docblock.description: Utility function to process the output from neighbours() and remove individual trunk ports leaving only single LAG links.
docblock.long-description:
For example, here's a sample return for a switch with a neighbour connected with a LAG / PortChannel:

array(2) {
["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(2) {
    [0] => array(11) {
        ["localPortId"] => int(10111)
        ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11"
        ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11"
        ["isLAG"] => bool(true)
        ["lagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
        ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11"
        ["remotePortId"] => int(10111)
        ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11"
        ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
    }
    [1] => array(11) {
        ["localPortId"] => int(10112)
        ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12"
        ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12"
        ["isLAG"] => bool(true)
        ["lagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
        ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12"
        ["remotePortId"] => int(10112)
        ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12"
        ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
    }
}
...
}

The result of this function would be:

array(2) {
["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(1) {
    [0] => array(11) {
        ["localPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Po48"
        ["localPort"] => string(21) "Po48"
        ["isLAG"] => bool(true)
        ["lagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
        ["remotePort"] => string(21) "Po48"
        ["remotePortId"] => int(5048)
        ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Po48"
        ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048)
        ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48"
    }
}
...
}

tag.name: param
tag.description: The result of a call to neighbours()

tag.name: return
tag.description: Processed CDP neighbours with LAG ports collapsed

docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values (first degree)
docblock.long-description:
Walks the SNMP tree returning an array of key => value pairs.

This is a first degree walk and it will throw an exception if there is more that one degree of values.

I.e. the following query with sample results:

walk1d( '.1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4' )

  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.1 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/1"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.2 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/2"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.3 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/3"
  .....

would yield an array:

 1 => GigabitEthernet1/0/1
 2 => GigabitEthernet1/0/2
 3 => GigabitEthernet1/0/3

tag.name: param
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

tag.name: throws
tag.description: On *any* SNMP error, warnings are supressed and a generic exception is thrown

docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values where they are indexed by IPv4 addresses
docblock.long-description:
I.e. the following query with sample results:

subOidWalk( '.1.3.6.1.2.1.15.3.1.1. )

  .1.3.6.1.2.1.15.3.1.1.10.20.30.4 = IpAddress: 192.168.10.10
  ...

would yield an array:

 [10.20.30.4] => "192.168.10.10"
 ....

tag.name: throws
tag.description: On *any* SNMP error, warnings are supressed and a generic exception is thrown

tag.name: param
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

docblock.description: Get the cache in use (or create a Cache\Basic instance
docblock.long-description:
We kind of mandate the use of a cache as the code is written with a cache in mind. You are free to disable it via disableCache() but your machines may be hammered!

We would suggest disableCache() / enableCache() used in pairs only when really needed.
